block.p: Seattle Failure Weighs On Future of Trade Talks While momentum is gathering behind the idea of a new round of global trade talks, fundamental differences between rich and poor nations and the United States and its trading partners over what should be on the agenda are clouding talks before they can begin.

The divisions follow a pattern that was largely evident before the failed meeting in Seattle in 1999. Mindful of the stakes, trade officials traveled to Geneva to try to advance the process. [World Business, Section W.]

Women Forced to Delay Retirement Hundreds of thousands of women in their 60's, part of the surge of divorces that started a generation ago, are finding they must stay in the work force because they lack the money to retire. Wages in effect are their pensions. [A1.]

A Response to Woody Allen's Suit Jean Doumanian, left, who was Woody Allen's closest friend for 30 years and produced some of his films, responded to a lawsuit he filed against her. She accused Mr. Allen of being ''self-indulgent'' and ''fiscally irresponsible'' in many of his films. Mr. Allen's suit contends that he had been cheated out of an unspecified amount of profits from eight movies. [C8.]

Justices Rule in Favor of Freelancers The Supreme Court ruled that a group of newspaper and magazine publishers infringed the copyrights owned by freelance contributors when the publishers made the writers' work available through electronic databases without their permission. [A1.]

Self-Cleaning Glass to Be Sold in U.S. Pilkington of Britain plans to outline its American sales plans for a window glass that cleans itself. PPG Industries in Pittsburgh is also working on the technology. [C5.]

Blue Chips Fall but Nasdaq Climbs Blue-chip stocks sagged but technology shares posted modest gains. The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 100.37 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 10,504.22. The Nasdaq composite index rose 16.03 points, or 0.8 percent, to 2,050.87. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 6.75 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,218.60. [C9.]

Home Resales Rose 2.9% in May Sales of previously owned homes rose 2.9 percent in May to the third-highest level as falling mortgage rates kept housing resistant to the economy's slowdown. Resales increased to an annual pace of 5.37 million houses from 5.22 million in April, the National Association of Realtors said. If the current rate holds, 5.25 million homes will sell this year. [C7.]
Canadian Company to Buy Miner Barrick Gold is buying Homestake Mining in a $2.3 billion deal. [World Business, Section W.]
California in Talks on Power Dispute California and the companies that sell it electricity sat at the same table to try to resolve a feud over the state's energy bills. [C7.]
U.S. Considers Buying B-2 Bombers The Pentagon is considering buying 40 more B-2 bombers, made by Northrop Grumman, for $735 million each. [A16.]

BMW Commissions Films for Web BMW has commissioned Web minidramas from well-known directors, who bring their particular feelings about cars to the short films. Elvis Mitchell: Critic's Notebook. [E1.]
